questions.question: What is the chemical formula for the compound Cu-ISOCN-1?
What method was used for the single X-ray structure determinations?
questions.answer: Single X-ray structure determinations were performed at 100 K on Bruker Kappa Diffractometers equipped with a Mo-Ka or Cu-Ka radiation source and an APEX-II CCD area detector.

questions.question: How was the disorder of the [PF6]– counteranion in Cu-ISOCN-1 handled during the crystallographic analysis?
questions.answer: The [PF6]– counteranion in Cu-ISOCN-1, which was positionally disordered, was modeled and refined anisotropically.

questions.question: What was the purpose of using the Platon routine SQUEEZE in the crystallographic analysis of Cu-ISOCN-1?
questions.answer: The Platon routine SQUEEZE was used to account for the electrons of highly disordered solvent molecules as a diffuse contribution to the overall scattering without specifying atom positions.

questions.question: True or False: The compound Cu-ISOCN-3 was analyzed using a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC 1 STARe System under a stream of dry dinitrogen gas.
What was the result of the CO2 sorption analysis performed on Cu-ISOCN-3 after activation at 200 °C?
questions.answer: The CO2 sorption analysis of activated Cu-ISOCN-3 revealed insignificant surface areas.

questions.question: True or False: The compound Cu-ISOCN-2 displayed significant porosity under N2 or CO2 gas during surface area analysis.
What computational method was used to study the [CNArMes2]2 compound?
questions.answer: Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the ORCA program package with the B3LYP/G hybrid functional and the 6-31G* basis set.

questions.question: How was the environmental stability of Cu-ISOCN-3 tested?
questions.answer: The environmental stability of Cu-ISOCN-3 was tested by suspending it in various solutions for 2-4 days, followed by drying and analysis.

questions.question: True or False: The compound Cu-ISOCN-3 is stable under atmospheric conditions indefinitely.
